text_data: Net neutrality is absolutely essential for a true democracy. Keep the FCC rules supporting net neutrality!
I strongly support preserving net neutrality backed by title II for ISPs.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
James Keene

It should have been obvious the last time this was attempted that the FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me and millions like me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!

I would like to comment on Net neutrality. I would like to recommend the government to repeal Tom Wheeler's decision to control Internet access. Individual citizens, not unelected bureaucrats, should be free to purchase the services we prefer. Tom Wheeler's decision to control Internet access is a corruption of the open Internet. It ended a market-based approach that worked supremely smoothly for many years with both parties' backing.

I'd like to share my thoughts on restoring Internet freedom. I would like to request Ajit Pai to overturn Obama's decision to take over Internet access. Individual Americans, not big government, should be free to purchase whichever applications they want. Obama's decision to take over Internet access is a perversion of net neutrality. It undid a light-touch system that performed supremely smoothly for two decades with both parties' approval.
The FCC should not be a puppet of internet companies. Do not mess with (NET NEUTRALITY) it is in place for a good reason.

To the Federal Communications Commission:  My comments re: internet regulations. I'd like to demand Ajit Pai to reverse President Obama's order to take over broadband. Individuals, as opposed to unelected bureaucrats, should be empowered to select the applications we want. President Obama's order to take over broadband is a distortion of net neutrality. It reversed a hands-off framework that worked fabulously well for decades with Republican and Democrat approval.

As an Internet user, I’m asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast free rein to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access rules we demanded and so recently won. 

I’m worried about creating a tiered Internet with “fast lanes” for certain sites or services because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current FCC regulations mean that ISP monopolies can’t slow or block Internet users’ access to certain websites or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging online services and websites more money to reach consumers faster. That’s the best way forward to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits consumers and small businesses as well as larger players. Chairman Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn ISPs into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

The internet provides endless creative opportunities and has allowed for people to be able to learn about other perspectives and other people. It allows us to connect with people and I believe that that connection and sharing of viewpoints helps kill hatred, prejudice, and ignorance. To make this change would be a crime. The internet can show the worst in humanity at times but it also allows us to come together as a whole and to be the best in humanity. 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.

Chairman Pai:  I'm very concerned about the FCC regulations on the Internet. I want to ask the Federal Communications Commission to repeal The Obama/Wheeler power grab to regulate the Internet. Americans, rather than unelected bureaucrats, deserve to purchase whichever services they prefer. The Obama/Wheeler power grab to regulate the Internet is a perversion of net neutrality. It stopped a hands-off system that worked supremely well for decades with bipartisan approval.
Freedom of speech, Freedom of the internet.  KEEP NET NEUTRALITY!!
I specifically support strong net neutrality backed by backed by Title 2 oversight of ISP's

Individual citizens, rather than the FCC, should be able to use which products we want. Barack Obama's order to take over the Internet is a betrayal of the open Internet. To the FCC:  I'm very worried about restoring Internet freedom. I strongly demand the Federal Communications Commission to undo Obama's power grab to control Internet access. Americans, not big government, should be able to purchase whichever products we choose. Obama's power grab to control Internet access is a perversion of net neutrality. It broke a market-based framework that worked remarkably successfully for many years with both parties' approval.

I'm here to submit my words of support for keeping ISPs classified beneath Title II. I'm a free market supporter, but Internet Service Providers do not operate under the conditions of the free market. In my city, there is only one option for Internet access at home: Cox Communications. While we have other ISPs available, such as Frontier Communications or satellite internet providers, these options are far too slow and far too expensive to be real options. There are no plans for these providers to change their services any time soon. 

There is no competition in the consumer ISP business. I HAVE to use Cox. I don't have a choice. So, if they decide to pick a favorite business, throttle Netflix, or Amazon, or Hulu because they've made a deal to deliver content more quickly, I cannot switch to another provider. The market is broken. Until new technology comes around to disrupt the physical cable to the home connection with as good or better connection speeds, latency, and reliability, Cox has a monopoly. Monopolies must be regulated. 

Don't reclassify ISPs and subject consumers to the whims of ISP corporations when we have no choice in the market.

Thomas Bermant

To the Federal Communications Commission:  I'd like to share my thoughts on the FCC's Open Internet order. I'd like to advocate the FCC to repeal Obama's decision to take over the web. People like me, rather than Washington bureaucrats, ought to enjoy the products they want. Obama's decision to take over the web is a betrayal of net neutrality. It stopped a pro-consumer approach that worked exceptionally well for decades with bipartisan approval.
I urge you to reconsider your stance on eliminating net neutrality. I do not believe that this is fair to the vast majority of Americans and small businesses.

Thankfully, the existing FCC regulations ensure that ISP monopolies can’t slow or block our access to certain websites or engage in data discrimination by charging online services and websites more money to reach consumers faster. That’s the best way forward to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai’s proposal would help turn Internet providers into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built.

Citizens, rather than unelected bureaucrats, should be able to use the applications we desire. Obama's power grab to control Internet access is a distortion of net neutrality. It ended a hands-off policy that functioned remarkably well for a long time with broad bipartisan support.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Casey Urtecho

I support strong net neutrality backed by title 2 over site of ISP's. Please don't allow corporate greed to dictate the access of information and content on the internet. 

Thank you

To the FCC:  I am a voter worried about the FCC rules on the Internet. I want to encourage the government to undo The Obama/Wheeler policy to control the web. Individual citizens, not unelected bureaucrats, should purchase whichever services we prefer. The Obama/Wheeler policy to control the web is a betrayal of the open Internet. It ended a light-touch framework that worked fabulously successfully for a long time with Republican and Democrat support.

Net Neutrality as we currently have it, is exactly what it describes: A Neutral Internet. Allowing ISPs to decide what people are allowed to browse by intentionally slowing down individual sites is an attack on our free internet highway.  An Internet that lets an ISP slow down sites Netflix because they (the ISP) are owned by a corporation with a competing service is an attack on American Values. Repealing Net Neutrality would give corporations and their ISPs the ability to censor the people and their voice, and that is absolutely unacceptable.
The idea of blocking sites is limiting my freedom, while I thought the USA is all about freedom, not communism.

Citizens, rather than the FCC Enforcement Bureau, should be free to purchase the services we want. Barack Obama's scheme to regulate the web is a distortion of the open Internet. It ended a free-market policy that performed fabulously successfully for decades with bipartisan backing.

Keep Net Neutrality. Leave our open internet alone. The American people already weighed in and over 4 million Americans commented when you last tried to change the rules of the internet. We the American people deserve a free and open internet.

Dear FCC,  I'm concerned about the future of the Internet. I'd like to urge you to reverse President Obama's decision to take over the web. lets see how it works

The FCC should stand up for Internet users by safeguarding net neutrality. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast the legal cover to throttle whatever they please, stripping users of the necessary privacy and access safeguards we worked for and just recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the current FCC regulations ensure that Internet providers can’t slow or block users’ ability to see certain websites or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging online services and websites more money to reach people faster. That’s the right kind of forward-looking approach to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn Internet providers into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new innovation and expression. That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

In a day and age when information is the greatest and most powerful currency in the world, the ability to access that information without interference-- especially interference for profit-- is essential. As both a citizen committed to staying well-informed and educated, and as the father of a child whose full and proper education depends on access to information, Net Neutrality is absolutely essential. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Phillip T Anderson

To repeat a concern voiced by others that I share.  I have long been a supporter of net neutrality and keeping the internet an open and uncensored resource for all Americans. The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them. I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest. Now is not the time (and there will never be a time) to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online. Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small. Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this. But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service. I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans. So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him. The internet is for all of the people, and should not be limited to the wealthy few. Thank you!

Dear FCC,  I'm very concerned about the future of the Internet. I strongly suggest the FCC to reverse Tom Wheeler's power grab to take over broadband. Individuals, not unelected bureaucrats, should be able to buy the services they desire. Tom Wheeler's power grab to take over broadband is a distortion of the open Internet. It disrupted a hands-off approach that worked exceptionally smoothly for a long time with Republican and Democrat consensus.

The FCC must protect the open Internet by maintaining net neutrality protections under Title II. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to give the government-subsidized ISP monopolies like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast free rein to throttle whatever they please, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access rules we worked for and won just two years ago. 

I’m afraid of a “pay-to-play” Internet where ISPs can charge more for certain websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the existing Open Internet rules mean that ISP monopolies can’t block or slow customers’ access to certain web services or engage in data discrimination by charging online services and websites money to reach consumers faster. That’s exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn Internet providers into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new innovation and expression. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that's not what we want. 

The internet has become the new virtual marketplace and information source for many people. If that open system becomes corrupted because ISPs can vary speeds to different websites it will irrevocably change the way people use the internet, and more importantly, will affect the freedom and diversity of the internet. Because of the role of the internet in the modern world, net neutrality must remain. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

To be completely honest, I simply don't believe when companies say that they will not abuse internet policies to favor themselves (or their allies). Therefore, without legal bounding and stringent oversight, we might have ourselves facing monopolies and trusts that would be completely bad for a free and fair use of the internet which is the right of every citizen of the world.
Net Neutrality needs to be kept in tact under Title II rules.  Undoing this regulation will do harm to consumers and the public in general.

Individual Americans, rather than unelected bureaucrats, should be able to select the products we desire. The previous administration's order to control Internet access is a corruption of net neutrality. It undid a hands-off approach that worked fabulously successfully for two decades with bipartisan approval.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Joshua M Ray

The internet's strength as a utility for the everyday man lives in its freedom and ease of access. Limiting a user's access based on the wishes of cable companies only hurts the poorest and most needy.  Allowing cable companies to dictate which companies have a fast lane and who has to wait for service gives them a monopoly on information, the consequences of which could be catastrophic and lead to deeper levels of corruption in our government and economic sectors.

Don't allow telecom companies to further monopolize their product.  Keep the internet free, PLEASE, for the common men and women of us who depend on the internet for economic and social relevance. Don't force us to the margins, because that's what this deal will do. 

Thanks for your earnest consideration. 
Brian Jackson

The FCC needs to stand up for Internet users like me and keep the net neutrality rules that are already in effect. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast the legal cover to engage in data discrimination, stripping Internet users of the vital access and privacy safeguards we demanded and won just two years ago. 

I’m worried about creating a tiered Internet with “fast lanes” for certain sites or services because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the existing net neutrality rules mean that ISPs can’t slow or block our access to certain web services or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging online services and websites money to reach people faster. That’s the right kind of forward-looking approach to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Pai’s proposal would transform ISPs into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on expression and innovation. That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

It's not up to corporations to determine how a free and open internet should function. The internet is such a powerful force in the world today precisely because it did not use data discrimination and everyone was on equal ground. Don't let coorporations profit on what so many have built. 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Dear FCC,  Hi, I'd like to comment on Net Neutrality and Title II. I strongly implore the commission to repeal Tom Wheeler's order to control the web. Internet users, rather than Washington, ought to purchase whichever products we prefer. Tom Wheeler's order to control the web is a perversion of net neutrality. It stopped a pro-consumer system that functioned very, very smoothly for a long time with bipartisan support.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Mr Pai:  I am concerned about the FCC regulations on the Internet. I'd like to ask the Federal Communications Commission to undo Obama's decision to take over the Internet. People like me, not the FCC, should enjoy whatever services they desire. Obama's decision to take over the Internet is a corruption of the open Internet. It stopped a market-based system that functioned very smoothly for a long time with both parties' support.

Don't screw this one up you guys.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them. 

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

To put it as simply as I can, the internet operates at the most basic level as a way of exchanging billions of billions of bits of data between terminal users (you) on a network (the world wide web).
Net Neutrality, at its essence guarantees that those who control the flow of that data treats all of them equally.
My data \xe2\x80\x93 the 1\xe2\x80\x99s and 0\xe2\x80\x99s that make up the web pages, pictures, songs, videos and cat memes I want to upload and download \xe2\x80\x93 are legally just as important as yours. This holds true even if we happen to be competitors arguing over who slows the whole network down by sending and receiving the most data.
The idea here is that if all of that data is treated equally, the internet can continue to operate as objectively as possible (some will argue with me on that point \xe2\x80\x93 and I hope they do) \xe2\x80\x93 and for as many people worldwide as possible.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to hand the government-subsidized telecom giants like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast the authority to engage in data discrimination, stripping Internet users of the necessary privacy and access protections we fought for and so recently won.

Chairman Pai’s proposal would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new expression and innovation. That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I am a recent college graduate, all of my work my efforts to find employment and the industry I wish to enter entirely depend on the internet. We as a people have benefited so much from the internet, every aspect of modern life is linked to the internet and would be impacted terribly if not outright destroyed by the loss of net neutrality, so pleas see reason and act responsibly. 

Thanks for protecting Internet users like me by upholding the existing Title II net neutrality rules.

Internet service providers should under no circumstances be permitted to favor one provider of digital content over another.  There is too much conflict of interest involved, too little oversight and little to no transparency in how these ISPs operate.  Keep Net Neutrality intact.

To whom it may concern:  In the matter of net neutrality rules. I ask the commissioners to overturn The Obama/Wheeler plan to take over the Internet. Individual citizens, not big government, should be free to select whichever products we want. The Obama/Wheeler plan to take over the Internet is a betrayal of net neutrality. It disrupted a hands-off system that performed fabulously successfully for two decades with broad bipartisan support.

To whom it may concern:  Regarding an open Internet. I'd like to advocate Ajit Pai to repeal Obama's order to regulate broadband. People like me, not Washington, should be free to enjoy whichever products we prefer. Obama's order to regulate broadband is a distortion of net neutrality. It reversed a market-based system that worked supremely smoothly for many years with bipartisan support.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Jacob Beethe

I fully support the current system of classification of all Internet Service Providers under Title 2. I do not support reclassification which would make ISPs voluntarily hold themselves​ accountable for providing equal and fair access to bandwidth and routing.

To whom it may concern:  Hi, I'd like to comment on regulations on the Internet. I would like to advocate the Federal Communications Commission to repeal Barack Obama's scheme to control the web. Americans, rather than Washington bureaucrats, should use which services they choose. Barack Obama's scheme to control the web is a betrayal of net neutrality. It ended a hands-off policy that functioned remarkably successfully for decades with both parties' approval.

It is imperative that the internet stay fair and open.  It would create unfair environment if anyone had the ability to gain faster access or slow a competitor's access down.  All web traffic must and should be treated equally.   The internet has become a vital part of our modern society.  It would be unconscionable to inhibit access to anyone, anywhere.

Please protect the right to access and net neutrality for ALL users.  As a consumer, I need to be in charge and able to control what I watch or do online. With the strongest possible emphasis--do the right thing for everyone--protect net neutrality.
The internet is a platform small businesses can get a start on. If communications businesses can control the traffic they are stifling the free market.
Keep strong Net Neutrality rules

Please keep Internet speed neutral to all sites from all providers. The point of the Internet is to provide equal access to all of those who are interested. Without this, ISPs could begin slowing down certain sites, or speeding up others. This selective throttling could effectively limit what websites are available to people, even more concerning when an ISP is acting towards pure profits or worse. In a society built on an educated electorate, this would not bode well. Keep the Internet equal and open to all. Perhaps one day any company could replace a poor actor as an ISP but here in Fayetteville for example, our options to pick an ISP are very few, thus giving great amounts of control to the ISPs. Net neutrality prevents abuse, collusion, social engineering and keeps an informed republic.
I specifically support strong net neutrality backed by Title 2 oversight of ISP's.  Removing title 2 will not be of benefit and is not in the best interest to the American people.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Stephanie Holmes

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Kenneth Distel
I don't want big companies deciding what I watch or do online.
Please preserve net neutrality and keep Title 2.  Thank you.

Dear FCC/Congress,

On behalf of the Republic of Internet Junkies, I would like to thank you for taking this time out to allow me to voice my concerns over net neutrality. 

Ever since it's inception followed by the establishment of the World Wide Web back in 1989/1990, the internet has proven itself to be one of the most powerful platform ever harvested to connect people from different corners of the world disregarding their races, ages, religions and political views. It is also proved itself to be a faster and (sometimes not necessarily) reliable tool to inform, thus also allowing people to express their freedom of speech, posting cat videos, and enjoy countless wonders of the internet. 

Now with the rise of the new administration, myself personally from a collective group of individuals, believes that our freedom and democracy should treat net neutrality  as an open field where people could post discussion, criticisms and personal opinions without restrictions and censorships that would potentially monopolized by giants and corporations who's scheme is to take over control of the government and turn their deep pockets into a business field that would eventually taking over the advantages of the people.

In the end, we strongly support net neutrality and our common beliefs that the internet should not be a source solely just for monetization and slowing down our internet providers service, but also a realm where different voices can be heard as well as providing an alternative pathway to the mainstream forms of entertainment. After all, the gaming and other various streaming industries need net neutrality more than ever to preserve our own unique culture and the similarities that we all share. 

Once again, thank you for taking this time off to review our concerns, and we've hoping that a reasonable and diplomatic solution shall be established to protect the very basic things that we love. 

Sincerely,
A Concerned Citizen

FCC commissioners,  I'm concerned about Internet regulation. I'd like to advocate the Federal Communications Commission to overturn The Obama/Wheeler power grab to regulate the Internet. Individual Americans, as opposed to Washington bureaucrats, should be free to buy which products we prefer. The Obama/Wheeler power grab to regulate the Internet is a perversion of the open Internet. It broke a free-market approach that worked fabulously well for a long time with both parties' approval.

Dear Mr. Pai,  Hi, I'd like to comment on Internet regulation and net neutrality. I would like to encourage Ajit Pai to reverse President Obama's plan to control the web. Individuals, not unelected bureaucrats, should select whichever services they choose. President Obama's plan to control the web is a distortion of net neutrality. It disrupted a light-touch system that performed very, very successfully for a long time with both parties' approval.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Reana Chowdhury

To the FCC:  Hi, I'd like to comment on Title II rules. I strongly request the Federal Communications Commission to undo Barack Obama's plan to regulate the Internet. Internet users, rather than so-called experts, deserve to purchase whatever services we desire. Barack Obama's plan to regulate the Internet is a perversion of net neutrality. It stopped a market-based system that functioned remarkably well for two decades with bipartisan consensus.

Internet has become a basic human need akin with water and power - the modern world cannot survive without it, and for it to reach its full potential, we need net neutrality. We need free and open communication, especially when companies already collude with anti-competitive practices creating defacto monopolies in the regions they serve. ISPs need to be regulated further, not less.  Keep the internet open. Defend net neutrality.

Chairman Pai:  My comments re: network neutrality regulations. I'd like to encourage the commission to reverse The Obama/Wheeler order to regulate the web. Citizens, as opposed to Washington, should be free to select the products they desire. The Obama/Wheeler order to regulate the web is a perversion of net neutrality. It undid a free-market approach that performed remarkably well for a long time with bipartisan backing.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Alycia Prasad

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Jeffrey S Witherspoon

Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Lunette Murrill

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Jacob Minneman

Instead of a pre-fabricated letter which will likely stagnate in redundancy, I wish to issue a personal statement of why I support net neutrality.

A free and open methodology of electronic communication is vital to the fluidity of a democratic society. There's a reason why we've referred to websites for specific community congregations as "forums" since their inception. To inhibit the accessibility of digital information and communication is to strike at the very historical core of public discourse, rational debate, and artistic expression. Every major and successful democracy in the history of human civilization has utilized their own version of a public forum. Inversely, every authoritarian, corrupt, and otherwise morally or progressively backwards system has sought to counteract the free flow of information and ideologies.

Net neutrality is about much more than who pays how much money for a network service.  It is about giving every voice and video feed an equal footing. It is about ensuring impoverished children can access free encyclopedias and the collective knowledge of human civilization anytime, anywhere, regardless of socioeconomic disenfranchisement. Net neutrality is about preserving free market principles and allowing individual merchants to openly and fairly compete with organizations that are orders of magnitude larger than themselves.  Computers and phones are by extension libraries and marketplaces in our pockets and homes, even if we choose not to use them or view them as such. It would be illegal for Congress to set rental prices for library books depending on who generated or provided the content, and likewise, by law there should be a laissez-faire approach to how such information is provided to the public. It would also be illegal for Congress to supersede the First Amendment rights of freedom of assembly.

As the son of a librarian and the thankful beneficiary of a democratic social structure, I firmly believe in the power of freely accessible information. Ending net neutrality will only benefit a select few who already tip the scales of justice with their economic clout, and will further the divide between the haves and the have nots.
Nick Ring

I'd like to share my thoughts on NET NEUTRALITY. I would like to advocate the FCC to rescind President Obama's scheme to take over broadband. Citizens, not the FCC, should be empowered to enjoy the products we choose. President Obama's scheme to take over broadband is a corruption of net neutrality. It stopped a light-touch system that functioned supremely successfully for a long time with broad bipartisan support.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Today's net neutrality rules require internet service providers, such as cable companies and other broadband providers, to treat all online traffic equally and allow users to visit any website and access any kind of content they want, whenever they want. Net neutrality rules have been working and these consumer protections should not be rolled back.

Preserving strong, enforceable net neutrality rules is fundamental to a free and open internet, and I urge you to protect the existing net neutrality rules to ensure the internet continues to be accessible for all equally.

Thank You
manuel mendez

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
James D Fields

FCC:  I want to give my opinion on the FCC regulations on the Internet. I strongly implore the commissioners to reverse Obama's order to regulate Internet access. Internet users, as opposed to unelected bureaucrats, should purchase whatever products they want. Obama's order to regulate Internet access is a distortion of net neutrality. It undid a market-based framework that performed very, very successfully for many years with both parties' support.

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T the authority to engage in data discrimination, stripping users of the meaningful access and privacy rules we demanded and just recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the current FCC regulations ensure that Internet providers can’t block or slow users’ access to certain web services or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging websites and online services money to reach people faster. That’s the right kind of forward-looking approach to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that's not what we want. 

I’m writing to urge you to keep our Open Internet rules based on Title II in place. Without them, we could lose the internet as we know it. 
The proposed changes to FCC rules would allow fast lanes for sites that pay, and force everyone else into slow lanes. We’ve already seen access to streaming services like Netflix, popular games like League of Legends, and communication platforms like FaceTime slowed down, or even blocked. Conditions like this hurt businesses large and small, and penalize the users who patronize them. 
The changes also open the door to unfair taxes on internet users, and could also make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can’t pay up to have their voices heard.
Please leave the existing net neutrality rules based on Title II in place.
Thank you! 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.

Dear FCC,  I'm very concerned about the future of the Internet. I would like to demand the government to rescind President Obama's power grab to regulate broadband. I absolutely oppose "restoring internet freedoms" (docket 17-108) and fully support net neutrality. I will actively campaign against any politician trying to push this matter through anyway. Therefore, I strongly support the regulation of ISPs under Title TWO, in order to maintain and enforce true net neutrality.

Dear Chairman Pai,  My comments re: network neutrality regulations. I demand the government to rescind The previous administration's scheme to control broadband. Americans, not so-called experts, should be free to use whichever products we want. The previous administration's scheme to control broadband is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It reversed a pro-consumer framework that worked exceptionally smoothly for a long time with both parties' support.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
James Mills

FCC:  I'm contacting you about Internet Freedom. I would like to demand the Federal Communications Commission to reverse President Obama's plan to regulate broadband. Individual Americans, rather than Washington, should be empowered to use whatever services they prefer. President Obama's plan to regulate broadband is a corruption of the open Internet. It disrupted a pro-consumer policy that worked remarkably smoothly for many years with nearly universal consensus.

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to hand the government-subsidized ISP monopolies like AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast the authority to throttle whatever they please, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access safeguards we worked for and so recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the existing net neutrality rules mean that Internet providers can’t block or slow customers’ ability to see certain websites or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging online services and websites more money to reach people faster. That’s exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as larger players. Pai’s proposal would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new innovation and expression. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that's not what we want. 

It's because it offers a wide variety of information and opportunities for growth. 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.
Preserve an open internet, keep net neutrality and title 2

Dear Commissioners:  I'd like to share my thoughts on regulations on the Internet. I would like to advocate the commission to overturn Obama's order to control Internet access. Americans, rather than unelected bureaucrats, deserve to purchase whatever applications we choose. Obama's order to control Internet access is a corruption of the open Internet. It reversed a hands-off policy that worked supremely well for two decades with bipartisan backing.

To the FCC:  Regarding NET NEUTRALITY. I encourage you to overturn The previous administration's decision to control the web. Individual Americans, as opposed to the FCC, deserve to use which services they want. The previous administration's decision to control the web is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It disrupted a hands-off framework that performed remarkably successfully for a long time with broad bipartisan approval.

Dear Chairman Pai,  In reference to the FCC's Open Internet order. I strongly recommend you to undo Obama's scheme to control the web. Individual citizens, as opposed to the FCC Enforcement Bureau, should be able to enjoy whatever applications we choose. Obama's scheme to control the web is a distortion of net neutrality. It stopped a hands-off system that functioned very, very successfully for decades with both parties' consensus.

To the FCC:  Regarding net neutrality. I'd like to urge the government to repeal President Obama's plan to control broadband. Individuals, rather than so-called experts, ought to use the services they want. President Obama's plan to control broadband is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It stopped a free-market system that worked exceptionally well for decades with nearly universal backing.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Joseph A Soto

Please maintain a free and open internet by NOT changing the current Net Neutrality rules . Maintain its regulation under Title II.  I understand this issue and believe that the regulations that were adopted under Chairman Genachowski's FCC  should be maintained.

Chairman Pai\xe2\x80\x99s proposed plan to repeal net neutrality protections would put a huge burden on microbusinesses like mine.

As an Etsy seller, net neutrality is essential to the success of my business and my ability to care for myself and my family. The FCC needs to ensure equal opportunities for microbusinesses to compete with larger and more established brands by upholding net neutrality protections.

Etsy has opened the door for me and 1.8 million other sellers to turn our passion into a business by connecting us to a global market of buyers. For 32% of creative entrepreneurs on the platform, our creative business is our sole occupation. A decrease in sales in the internet slow lane or higher cost to participate in Chairman Pai\xe2\x80\x99s pay-to-play environment would create significant obstacles for me and other Etsy sellers to care for ourselves and our families.

Moreover, 87% of Etsy sellers in the U.S. are women, and most run their microbusinesses out of their homes. By rolling back the bright line rules that ensure net neutrality, Chairman Pai is not only taking away our livelihood, he is also putting up barriers to entrepreneurship for a whole cohort of Americans.

My business growth depends on equal access to consumers. Any rule that allows broadband providers to negotiate special deals with some companies would undermine my ability to compete online.

We need a free and open internet that works for everyone, not just telecom companies that stand to benefit from the FCC\xe2\x80\x99s proposed rules.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding and to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II and microbusinesses like mine.

Thank you!
Sandy Kraemer
