You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Luan Tran
I am very upset that ISPs would be able to throttle my internet speeds.

Dear FCC,  I am a voter worried about Net Neutrality and Title II. I want to advocate the government to rescind The previous administration's plan to take over broadband. Individual citizens, not Washington bureaucrats, ought to purchase the services we desire. The previous administration's plan to take over broadband is a corruption of the open Internet. It reversed a free-market framework that performed remarkably successfully for many years with nearly universal support.

FCC commissioners,  Hi, I'd like to comment on net neutrality. I demand the commission to reverse Barack Obama's plan to control broadband. Citizens, as opposed to unelected bureaucrats, should be empowered to purchase whichever services we desire. Barack Obama's plan to control broadband is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It ended a light-touch policy that worked exceptionally well for a long time with bipartisan approval.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. To whom it may concern:  In reference to Net neutrality. I strongly ask you to rescind President Obama's policy to take over broadband. People like me, rather than the FCC Enforcement Bureau, ought to buy whichever services we choose. President Obama's policy to take over broadband is a betrayal of the open Internet. It ended a light-touch system that worked very well for decades with bipartisan approval.

I support the existing Net Neutrality rules, which classify internet service providers under the Title II provision of the Telecommunications Act. 

There are already issues with ISP providers having geographic monopolies in most areas in the USA. Rolling back these provisions do nothing but hurt consumers and put money in the pockets of companies with no competition. Not to mention arbitrary data caps which are used by these companies to squeeze money out of consumers.

As a software engineer my job relies on an open and free internet. Please DO NOT roll back these regulations. Thank you for your time and a platform to give my view.

An open and free internet is perhaps the greatest advancement in human interaction and progress.  Restricting or throttling content will stifle innovation and further advances in economic, philosophical, and humanitarian pursuits, to  name a few.  
As I look to the future and hope to realize creating and owning my own construction company I will no longer be able to compete with larger companies to reach new customers and clients.  I will be shut out of the market because I will not have a marketing budget to compare with the largest companies.
The other concern that I have is I do not have a choice of provider for my ISP address as my town is contracted with only one provider.  If my provider decides to drop my internet speeds, or make me pay more for what would be a comparable speed today, I have no recourse.  I would be forced to pay an increased price for my current services, for no other reason than a change in the law.  This would hinder my ability to connect with current friends and family.  I am also an avid volleyball player and slower speed, or lack of access to certain sites would hinder my ability to meet people and play a sport I love.
Please keep the 2015 rules as they will allow the United States to be the great country it is.

To the Federal Communications Commission:  I am concerned about Net neutrality. I strongly request the FCC to repeal The Obama/Wheeler order to take over the web. People like me, as opposed to big government, should be free to purchase which services we want. The Obama/Wheeler order to take over the web is a betrayal of net neutrality. It ended a market-based framework that worked very, very well for a long time with both parties' consensus.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Ryan McAnulty

Dear Mr. Pai,  With respect to restoring Internet freedom. I would like to advocate the Federal Communications Commission to repeal President Obama's plan to control the Internet. Citizens, as opposed to Washington, should be empowered to use which services they choose. President Obama's plan to control the Internet is a perversion of net neutrality. It stopped a light-touch approach that functioned very smoothly for decades with both parties' backing.

In reference to net neutrality rules. I would like to encourage the FCC to overturn Barack Obama's policy to take over Internet access. Citizens, as opposed to Washington, should be empowered to enjoy whatever applications we desire. Barack Obama's policy to take over Internet access is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It undid a light-touch policy that performed fabulously well for a long time with nearly universal backing.

The FCC needs to stand up for Internet users like me and keep the net neutrality rules that are already in effect. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to hand the telecom giants like Verizon, AT&T, and Comcast free rein to create Internet fast lanes, stripping users of the necessary privacy and access safeguards we worked for and so recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the existing FCC regulations mean that Internet providers can’t block or slow users’ ability to see certain websites or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging websites and online services money to reach customers faster. That’s the right kind of forward-looking approach to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposal would help turn ISPs into gatekeepers with the ability to veto new expression and innovation. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that's not what we want. 

It gives me a chance to be exposed to opinions, facts, art, and stories I'd never get to hear on my own. It gave me the chance to tell my mother about the terrorist attacks in her country of origin and the people who live there and were being affected by it to tell the world what was going on and call for help. It gives people all over the world the chance to call for help and call for change, something we desperately need. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.

Restoring Internet Freedom? Are you kidding me? If you want to restore internet freedom, then undo the government mandate that prevents me from freely choosing my internet service provider. Until that time, the FCC better do everything in its power to protect my internet freedom. The new FCC Chairman claims there was no proof that companies like Comcast and ATT have been throttling legal services, and yet all he has to do is look at the mounds of evidence collected stating that in fact companies like Comcast and ATT have used their position to degrade the quality of service of products, sites, and services or requiring consumers to pay more to access competitors services that compete with their own. In fact, ATT is doing that now by saying that their own services do not count against their self imposed data caps. The zero rating program clearly states that there is no extra charge to use their own services, but if a consumer wants to use a competitors service (and remember consumers cannot freely choose ISPs because of the FCC) they will have to use their allotted bandwidth our pay more. There are only two ways to protect internet freedom. Restore the ability of consumers to freely choose any internet service provider they want OR prevent internet service providers from degrading the quality of service of competing services by pressuring Net Neutrality.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

Today's net neutrality rules require internet service providers, such as cable companies and other broadband providers, to treat all online traffic equally and allow users to visit any website and access any kind of content they want, whenever they want. Net neutrality rules have been working and these consumer protections should not be rolled back.

Preserving strong, enforceable net neutrality rules is fundamental to a free and open internet, and I urge you to protect the existing net neutrality rules to ensure the internet continues to be accessible for all equally.

Thank You
Alexander Francisco

Dear FCC,  I'm very concerned about the FCC rules on the Internet. I'd like to advocate you to overturn The Obama/Wheeler plan to regulate the web. Chairman Pai:  In reference to the future of the Internet. I'd like to advocate the commissioners to overturn President Obama's decision to regulate broadband. Individual Americans, rather than unelected bureaucrats, should be empowered to purchase the applications we prefer. President Obama's decision to regulate broadband is a corruption of the open Internet. It broke a pro-consumer policy that worked very successfully for many years with Republican and Democrat approval.

The FCC should safeguard Internet freedom by keeping the bright-line net neutrality protections in place and upholding Title II. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to give the government-subsidized ISP monopolies like Verizon, Comcast, and AT&T the legal cover to engage in data discrimination, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access rules we worked for and just recently won. 

I’m worried about creating a tiered Internet with “fast lanes” for certain sites or services because there's a serious lack of competition in ISP's. That’s exactly the right balance to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new expression and innovation. That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

The Internet is our access to modern commerce. Lack of ISP competition stifles economic growth and makes us uncompetitive with other developed countries. Americans pay more than most developed countries for a slower Internet connection. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.

To the Federal Communications Commission:  I'm a voter worried about the FCC's Open Internet order. I suggest the commissioners to reverse Obama's decision to regulate the web. Internet users, as opposed to unelected bureaucrats, deserve to purchase whatever applications we desire. Obama's decision to regulate the web is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It reversed a pro-consumer approach that performed remarkably successfully for two decades with nearly universal consensus.

Keep net neutrality under title II.

A free and open internet is central to our democracy. It allows small businesses to compete against large companies, it ensures freedom of information and freedom of speech for all citizens. ISPs should not have the power to decide what information we get, or what companies we support. Keeping net neutrality under title II regulations is essential for preventing this from happening. Please consider supporting the people of this country, and not the large corporations that are the only ones to benefit from this. Keep net neutrality under title II

The key principle on which this nation was founded on was freedom, specifically freedom of information and the ability to share that information, be it through speech, the press, religion, or so forth. In this new era of information, it could be reasonably stated that freedom to explore the internet and its vast wealth of knowledge is as important as the freedom we have to travel where we please, to roam freely. Ending net neutrality would be the equivalent of barring access to certain genres of literature at a public library unless an additional surcharge is paid for that type. Preventing our citizens from ascertaining knowledge is a sure way to plunge this nation into a state of ignorance and oppression, and is the first step towards the heinous violation of our sacred rights of freedom that we as a people have fought so hard to achieve and maintain for hundreds of years; this would be the first piercing wound of many others that would profusely hemorrhage freedom until the well of liberty ran dry. 

No more. The people have spoken, they have risen up and said "No. You will not take our freedom unless it is from our cold, dead hands." It's time to end the battle for net neutrality, because if we lose, the battle for our remaining freedom will have only just begun.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Mark Sweigart

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Brandon Frateschi

Dear Mr. Pai,  I'm a voter worried about Title II rules. I'd like to demand the Federal Communications Commission to reverse President Obama's decision to control the web. Individual Americans, as opposed to Washington bureaucrats, should purchase which services they choose. President Obama's decision to control the web is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It broke a free-market system that worked exceptionally successfully for a long time with bipartisan approval.

Chairman Pai’s proposed plan to repeal net neutrality protections would put a huge burden on microbusinesses like mine.

As an Etsy seller, net neutrality is essential to the success of my business and my ability to care for myself and my family. The FCC needs to ensure equal opportunities for microbusinesses to compete with larger and more established brands by upholding net neutrality protections.

Etsy has opened the door for me and 1.8 million other sellers to turn our passion into a business by connecting us to a global market of buyers. For 32% of creative entrepreneurs on the platform, our creative business is our sole occupation. A decrease in sales in the internet slow lane or higher cost to participate in Chairman Pai’s pay-to-play environment would create significant obstacles for me and other Etsy sellers to care for ourselves and our families.

Moreover, 87% of Etsy sellers in the U.S. are women, and most run their microbusinesses out of their homes. By rolling back the bright line rules that ensure net neutrality, Chairman Pai is not only taking away our livelihood, he is also putting up barriers to entrepreneurship for a whole cohort of Americans.

My business growth depends on equal access to consumers. Any rule that allows broadband providers to negotiate special deals with some companies would undermine my ability to compete online.

We need a free and open internet that works for everyone, not just telecom companies that stand to benefit from the FCC’s proposed rules.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding and to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II and microbusinesses like mine.

Thank you!
Tiffany Darst

Rolling back net neutrality rules would be a devastating blow to Americans and the principle of free and fair markets. The Internet is no longer a luxury, and has not been for a while. It is essential to the function of our economy and will be even more so going into the future. By eliminating the 2015 Net Neutrality rules you would be allowing a select few corporations in an oligopoly to stifle innovation and competition by charging higher rates to companies for priority access to their end users (or possible even access at all), thus increasing barriers to enter digital content markets. Similarly, you would allow those same few corporations to charge more to their end users for not throttling their connection to high bandwidth services. Telecommunications companies, specifically the ones that offer broadband Internet, already have a monopoly in most places in the United States, so the argument that users that see higher prices would simply switch to another ISP is ridiculous. There is no free market when it comes to ISP choice for the vast majority of Americans. Where there is a free market is online with digital content providers and online retailers. Eliminating net neutrality will be granting a few large corporations the ability to further gouge their customers while reducing free market competition online.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
JEREMY QUINTIN

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Bryan Bustos

Dear FCC,  I am concerned about the FCC regulations on the Internet. I strongly encourage the FCC to undo The Obama/Wheeler plan to take over the Internet. Dear FCC,

I'm writing to express my serious concern with the Net Neutrality issue.  We MUST keep the current law whereby Internet service providers should enable access to all content and applications regardless of the source, and without favoring or blocking particular products or websites.  Do not succumb to the Fascist direction the U.S. is being led by restricting access to information and being subjeced to unsolicitied influence from 3rd parties. 

Net Neutrality is the way the Internet has always worked...Chairman Pai is putting pressure on the FCC to change it and it's criminally wrong and certainly NOT in the best interests of our Democracy and controlling our access to whatever sites we choose and the ability to communicate freely.

Keep Title II in place for Net Neutrality.  We are watching you and we WILL hold you accountable!  Stop this Fascist BS now!

Stacey Lane

Due to corporations' stranglehold over our current internet technology, there is not enough competition among Internet Service Providers across America to provide good internet service, or service that a particular group of customers want (e.g. options for ISPs with net neutrality, ISPs with prioritized content, or ISPs with better upload speed). Taking this into consideration, at present our best option to continue providing the majority of Americans with the internet they want and need, is to support Net Neutrality.

This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Marshall Shaw

Etsy Shop https://www.etsy.com/shop/NorthStarFibers

Chairman Pai's proposed plan to repeal net neutrality protections would put a huge burden on microbusinesses like mine.

As an Etsy seller, net neutrality is essential to the success of my business and my ability to care for myself and my family. The FCC needs to ensure equal opportunities for microbusinesses to compete with larger and more established brands by upholding net neutrality protections.

Etsy has opened the door for me and 1.8 million other sellers to turn our passion into a business by connecting us to a global market of buyers. For 32% of creative entrepreneurs on the platform, our creative business is our sole occupation. A decrease in sales in the internet slow lane or higher cost to participate in Chairman Pai's pay-to-play environment would create significant obstacles for me and other Etsy sellers to care for ourselves and our families.

Moreover, 87% of Etsy sellers in the U.S. are women, and most run their microbusinesses out of their homes. By rolling back the bright line rules that ensure net neutrality, Chairman Pai is not only taking away our livelihood, he is also putting up barriers to entrepreneurship for a whole cohort of Americans.

My business growth depends on equal access to consumers. Any rule that allows broadband providers to negotiate special deals with some companies would undermine my ability to compete online.

We need a free and open internet that works for everyone, not just telecom companies that stand to benefit from the FCC's proposed rules.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding and to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II and microbusinesses like mine.

The FCC should safeguard Internet freedom by keeping the bright-line net neutrality protections in place and upholding Title II. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the legal cover to engage in data discrimination, stripping users of the necessary privacy and access rules we demanded and just recently won. 

I’m afraid of a “pay-to-play” Internet where ISPs can charge more for certain websites because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules mean that ISP monopolies can’t slow or block our access to certain web services or engage in data discrimination by charging online services and websites more money to reach consumers faster. That’s exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposal would transform Internet providers into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

It's a way to educate and learn, a place to travel and see new things, a place to work and rest. We need less government control over our lives , we're supposed to be a free people but we are not. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.

I respectfully request that this planet maintain net neutrality. We will always have bad neighbors and yet we must live as one. Bad is out there so please give us good guys support in having the opportunity to fully realize the dreams of all mankind.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Earl O Jones

Individual Americans, as opposed to big government, deserve to select the applications they choose. Tom Wheeler's power grab to take over the Internet is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It reversed a light-touch approach that performed very, very smoothly for two decades with nearly universal consensus.
I am a youtuber and I do not want this to happen. Protect net neutrality so I can continue making youtube videos.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
James Joseph

FCC:  I'm a voter worried about Internet regulation. I would like to suggest you to undo The Obama/Wheeler plan to control the web. As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Rodney Moore

Americans, not unelected bureaucrats, deserve to select the services we choose. The previous administration's decision to control the web is a corruption of net neutrality. It ended a hands-off framework that performed very successfully for decades with broad bipartisan support.

As an Internet user, I’m asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to hand the government-subsidized ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon free rein to throttle whatever they please, stripping consumers of the vital privacy and access protections we demanded and so recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the existing Open Internet rules mean that Internet providers can’t block or slow consumers’ ability to see certain web services or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging websites and online services money to reach people faster. That’s the best way forward to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposal would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with the ability to veto new innovation and expression. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Dear Commissioners:  I have concerns about net neutrality. I want to suggest the Federal Communications Commission to overturn The previous administration's power grab to take over the Internet. Internet users, not so-called experts, should be free to use the services we prefer. The previous administration's power grab to take over the Internet is a perversion of the open Internet. It stopped a light-touch approach that performed very smoothly for two decades with broad bipartisan consensus.
I specifically support strong net neutrality backed by Title II oversight ISPs. Ajit Pai is a danger to our country.

With all the data already being collected by corporations on internet users, we're already being pushed around too much with not being in control of what we see and do online for other's profit. I can't think of a single reason of y'all doing this that isn't one of the seven deadly sins. Greed and control. Net neutrality needs to stay. This kind of control is already corrupt, but can get extremely worse fast. I mean, are we gonna be one of those countries to cover up things like the holocaust? Do we really wanna be labeled as THOSE guys? Well, I guess to you guys as long as you get what you want everyone else can get lost.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Ben Wahrman

I want to suggest the Federal Communications Commission to overturn President Obama's scheme to take over the Internet. Internet users, as opposed to so-called experts, should use the applications we desire. President Obama's scheme to take over the Internet is a distortion of the open Internet. Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Diego Mendoza
The internet has many free things that are needed in this day in age and to practically take it away for your own selfish gain is just wrong

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me, and having all ISPs adhere to Title 2 is extremely important for the future of this nation and the world. I strongly support net neutrality backed by Title 2 oversight of ISPs. I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest. Now is not the time (and there will never be a time) to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online. Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small. Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this. But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service. I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans. So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him. The internet is for all of the people, and should not be limited to the wealthy few. Thank you!  Charles Evans

We need the FCC to defend the rights of millions of Internet users by upholding net neutrality protections. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the telecom giants like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T free rein to throttle whatever they please, stripping consumers of the necessary privacy and access protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules mean that ISP monopolies can’t slow or block customers’ ability to see certain websites or engage in data discrimination by charging websites and online services more money to reach consumers faster. That’s the best way forward to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as larger players. Pai’s proposal would transform ISPs into gatekeepers with the ability to veto new innovation and expression. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that's not what we want. 

The internet allows me to do my work, stay in touch with friends and family, and feel like I have the power to research ways to fight back against oppressive regimes. Controlling what people can and can't access online is a step towards Fascism. I'm not about to give up my freedom just like that. 

Thanks for protecting Internet users like me by upholding the existing Title II net neutrality rules.

Dear Chairman Pai,  I would like to comment on the future of the Internet. I want to advocate Ajit Pai to undo Obama's power grab to control the Internet. People like me, rather than Washington bureaucrats, should be able to enjoy whichever applications they desire. Obama's power grab to control the Internet is a betrayal of net neutrality. It ended a market-based approach that functioned very, very well for many years with bipartisan approval.

Dear Commissioners:  Regarding Internet freedom. I would like to encourage the FCC to undo The previous administration's policy to regulate the Internet. Americans, not the FCC Enforcement Bureau, should use the applications they choose. The previous administration's policy to regulate the Internet is a corruption of the open Internet. It undid a pro-consumer policy that worked fabulously smoothly for many years with Republican and Democrat approval.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!

To the FCC:  I'm concerned about net neutrality. I implore you to undo Barack Obama's decision to control the web. People like me, as opposed to the FCC, should be empowered to purchase which products they prefer. Barack Obama's decision to control the web is a betrayal of the open Internet. It stopped a pro-consumer approach that worked fabulously smoothly for two decades with broad bipartisan approval.

Dear Chairman Pai,  I am concerned about Internet Freedom. I strongly demand Ajit Pai to rescind The Obama/Wheeler power grab to control broadband. Americans, not big government, ought to use the services we prefer. The Obama/Wheeler power grab to control broadband is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It stopped a pro-consumer policy that functioned fabulously successfully for two decades with Republican and Democrat backing.

Net neutrality is an important concept that is necessary to keep in effect. The consumers of Internet Service Providers as well as smaller companies' websites will be affected greatly and negatively. Consumers will be pulled into paying more for specific uses of their internet, and small companies will likely be unable to pay any fees for the Internet Service Providers to gain access to faster internet channels, thus receiving a much smaller amount of traffic. If any company that either is unable to or refuses to pay the Internet Service Providers relies on their websites for profit to ANY extent, they lose a large amount of profit and could potentially become bankrupt. Seeing as the "American Dream" involves being able to create your own businesses and being able to acheive anything with hard work and dedication, this would go against that value and hamper many people's opportunities. There are so many companies and individuals against the repeal of Net Neutrality, so for the sake of the people please keep it in effect. The people who would be benefited would be the gigantic companies and the extremely rich, and anyone else would be smothered by it. I urge you to keep Net Neutrality, as do many many others.

As an Internet user, I'm asking the FCC to protect the net neutrality protections currently in place. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai's proposal to give the ISP monopolies like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the authority to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the meaningful access and privacy protections we fought for and just recently won. 

I'm concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites, because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules ensure that Internet providers can't slow or block our ability to see certain websites or create Internet "fast lanes" by charging websites and online service money to reach customers faster. That's exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as larger players. Pai's proposed repeal of the rules would transform ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That's not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

I urge you to keep Title II net neutrality in place, and safeguard Internet users like me.

Sincerely,
Kristie Williams

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Derek Lion

Net neutrality is what made the internet the great thing it is today. It is critically important that no bit is prioritized above any other. Preserve strong protections for a free and open internet, so that no company can pay to give it's data priority over any other bit of data.

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like Verizon,  AT&T, and Comcast free rein to throttle whatever they please, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access rules we demanded and just recently won. 

I’m worried about creating a tiered Internet with “fast lanes” for certain sites or services because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the existing FCC regulations ensure that ISP monopolies can’t block or slow users’ ability to see certain web services or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging websites and online service more money to reach customers faster. That’s exactly the right balance to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits Internet users and small businesses as well as larger players. Pai’s proposal would transform Internet providers into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s not how the Internet was built, and that not what we want. 

I spend most of my time online in one way or another. If my Internet becomes a series of monetized channels and nothing else we may as well go back to AOL for all the good it will do us. 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.

Mr Pai:  I'm very concerned about the FCC rules on the Internet. I'd like to urge Ajit Pai to undo The Obama/Wheeler plan to control Internet access. Individual Americans, not big government, ought to buy whichever products we desire. The Obama/Wheeler plan to control Internet access is a distortion of net neutrality. It ended a market-based framework that functioned remarkably smoothly for many years with Republican and Democrat consensus.
Please DO NOT loosen regulations on Net Neutrality. It is important for obvious reason...greedy people exist and take advantage of the system if allowed.
I don't want to pay extra fr things, have ads shoved in my face, and have the content I view filtered by large companies searching for profit.

Net neutrality needs to be preserved. Title II has to remain in effect to prevent ISPs to give unfair advantage to certain services for their own gain.

Furthermore, it has allowed me to connect with friends and family spread far across the globe.

You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Jarrod Thompson
Please do not destroy net neutrality. Our country needs a free and open Internet.
I believe Net neutrality is be protected to keep America truly a democratic country with the freedoms that we have given our young men and women over the years to protect.

To whom it may concern:  Hi, I'd like to comment on restoring Internet freedom. I want to urge Ajit Pai to overturn Tom Wheeler's order to take over broadband. People like me, rather than unelected bureaucrats, ought to select whichever applications we desire. Tom Wheeler's order to take over broadband is a corruption of the open Internet. It undid a light-touch framework that worked fabulously smoothly for a long time with Republican and Democrat backing.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. We need the FCC to defend the rights of millions of Internet users by upholding net neutrality protections. 

The FCC should reject Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to give the government-subsidized telecom giants like Comcast, AT&T, and Verizon the legal cover to throttle whatever they please, stripping consumers of the necessary access and privacy safeguards we demanded and won just two years ago.

That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users.

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the telecom giants like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T the legal cover to engage in data discrimination, stripping consumers of the meaningful access and privacy protections we demanded and so recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because users will have fewer options and a less diverse Internet. Thankfully, the existing Open Internet rules mean that Internet providers can’t slow or block our access to certain web services or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging online services and websites more money to reach consumers faster. That’s the right kind of forward-looking approach to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits consumers and small businesses as well as larger players. Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn Internet providers into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on innovation and expression. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

The internet is one of the few places where big corporations have not bullied everyone else away. 

Thank you for keeping Title II net neutrality rules in place to protect Internet users like me.

The FCC needs to stand up for Internet users like me and keep the net neutrality rules that are already in effect. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to give the ISP monopolies like AT&T, Comcast, and Verizon free rein to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the vital access and privacy rules we fought for and just recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because I want to pay for an internet connection without supporting services from large corporations that I do not need or want. Thankfully, the existing Open Internet rules mean that Internet providers can’t block or slow users’ ability to see certain websites or engage in data discrimination by charging websites and online service money to reach consumers faster. That’s exactly the right balance to make sure competition in the Internet space is fair and benefits small businesses and consumers as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposal would help turn ISPs into Internet gatekeepers with an effective veto right on expression and innovation. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

I don't use most of the major services that would get the fast lane treatment, I do a lot of overseas browsing and hosting of services for small communities. Without net neutrality I would find myself unwillingly paying for services which I do not need or want, I do not want to pay to make large corporations larger, I want to pay for an internet connection and make my own decisions. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.
I wish for the FCC to ensure net neutrality to avoid giving Internet Service Providers the ability to control what I see over the internet.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you!
Vincent Yiu

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s proposal to hand the ISP monopolies like AT&T, Comcast, and Verizon the legal cover to engage in data discrimination, stripping users of the vital access and privacy safeguards we fought for and just recently won. 

I’m afraid of a “pay-to-play” Internet where ISPs can charge more for certain websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the current FCC regulations mean that Internet providers can’t block or slow users’ access to certain web services or engage in data discrimination by charging websites and online services money to reach customers faster. That’s the best way forward to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and consumers as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposal would help turn ISPs into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on expression and innovation. That’s contrary to the basic precepts on which the Internet was built. 

I make my living in Information Security, and I spend leisure time with my family watching streaming movies and other shows.  I am very concerned about giving ISP's the arbitrary ability to police themselves, and to not put limits on bandwidth for sites that may compete directly with their interests. 

I appreciate you maintaining Title II net neutrality rules and the rights of Internet users like me.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.

Thank you! 
Josh

Dear FCC,  With respect to the FCC's Open Internet order. I request the FCC to overturn Obama's decision to control Internet access. Citizens, rather than the FCC, ought to enjoy whatever applications they prefer. Obama's decision to control Internet access is a exploitation  of net neutrality. It broke a free-market approach that worked exceptionally successfully for decades with both parties' approval.

Chairman Pai:  I have concerns about the FCC's so-called Open Internet order. I would like to advocate Ajit Pai to repeal Obama's plan to control broadband. Individuals, not Washington bureaucrats, should be free to purchase which applications they desire. Obama's plan to control broadband is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It reversed a light-touch framework that worked very smoothly for decades with both parties' approval.

FCC:  I am concerned about network neutrality regulations. I want to request the FCC to reverse The Obama/Wheeler order to take over Internet access. Individual citizens, rather than Washington bureaucrats, ought to select whatever applications we desire. The Obama/Wheeler order to take over Internet access is a exploitation  of the open Internet. It broke a pro-consumer system that functioned supremely successfully for a long time with both parties' backing.

The FCC Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.  I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, make some more accessible than others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.  Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.  Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay—and slow lanes for everyone else—if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.  Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer fast lanes to websites for a fee, and Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do just this.  But if you let ISPs make some websites fast and others artificially slow—for a fee—you will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America—just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.  I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.  So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support Title II rules and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.  Thank you!

The FCC should ensure a fair and open Internet for all by opposing efforts to undermine net neutrality. 

The FCC should throw out Chairman Ajit Pai’s plan to hand the telecom giants like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T free rein to create Internet fast lanes, stripping Internet users of the vital privacy and access rules we fought for and so recently won. 

I’m concerned about ISPs being allowed to discriminate against certain types of data or websites because ISPs could have too much power to determine what I can do online. Thankfully, the current net neutrality rules mean that ISPs can’t slow or block Internet users’ ability to see certain websites or create Internet “fast lanes” by charging websites and online services money to reach consumers faster. That’s exactly the right balance to ensure the Internet remains a level playing field that benefits small businesses and Internet users as well as entrenched Internet companies. Chairman Pai’s proposed repeal of the rules would help turn ISPs into gatekeepers with an effective veto right on expression and innovation. That’s not the kind of Internet we want to pass on to future generations of technology users. 

It's a place to meet people and be yourself. 

Thanks for protecting Internet users like me by upholding the existing Title II net neutrality rules.

The internet has become a staple in all our lives and every single person uses it. I believe it is our right to have a free and open internet where our privacy is untampered with and we see what we choose to see, not companies who have the deepest pockets. Our lawmakers should be ashamed that this issue even exists, as I'm sure they all have skeletons in their e-closets so to speak.

The FCC's Open Internet Rules (net neutrality rules) are extremely important to me. I urge you to protect them.

I don't want ISPs to have the power to block websites, slow them down, give some sites an advantage over others, or split the Internet into "fast lanes" for companies that pay and "slow lanes" for the rest.

Now is not the time to let giant ISPs censor what we see and do online.

Censorship by ISPs is a serious problem. Comcast has throttled Netflix, AT&T blocked FaceTime, Time Warner Cable throttled the popular game League of Legends, and Verizon admitted it will introduce fast lanes for sites that pay-and slow lanes for everyone else-if the FCC lifts the rules. This hurts consumers and businesses large and small.

Courts have made clear that if the FCC ends Title II classification, the FCC must let ISPs offer "fast lanes" to websites for a fee.

Chairman Pai has made clear that he intends to do exactly this.

But if some companies can pay our ISPs to have their content load faster, startups and small businesses that can't pay those fees won't be able to compete. You will kill the open marketplace that has enabled millions of small businesses and created the 5 most valuable companies in America-just to further enrich a few much less valuable cable giants famous for sky-high prices and abysmal customer service.

Internet providers will be able to impose a private tax on every sector of the American economy.

Moreover, under Chairman Pai's plan, ISPs will be able to make it more difficult to access political speech that they don't like. They'll be able to charge fees for website delivery that would make it harder for blogs, nonprofits, artists, and others who can't pay up to have their voices heard.

I'm sending this to the FCC's open proceeding, but I worry that Chairman Pai, a former Verizon lawyer, has made his plans and will ignore me and millions of other Americans.

So I'm also sending this to my members of Congress. Please publicly support the FCC's existing net neutrality rules based on Title II, and denounce Chairman Pai's plans. Do whatever you can to dissuade him.
